title: Has quarantine made you more or less social? - Quora

response.answer_text: Ironically, I’ve actually been more social since the quarantine began here four weeks ago. That’s because I wasn’t all that social to begin with. I never went to bars or restaurants or the movies anyway. The only place that I really want to go now, but I can’t go because of the quarantine, is the barber. Other than that, all of the places I normally go are still open, because I mostly go to “essential” places anyway: grocery and hardware stores. But now, since I’m home all day like everyone else, I’m doing a lot more walking my dog/riding my bike/hanging out in my yard. Except everyone else in the neighborhood is doing the same thing, which means there are a lot more friendly greetings and short conversations from an appropriate distance. I taught at a school in my neighborhood for a few years until it closed. I know a lot of my neighbors as parents of students I once taught. Now, since we’re all outside a lot more, I’ve re-connected with some of those parents, and even some of the students who were forced to move back home from college. I’ve engaged in small talk with more people over the last month than I did the previous six months.

In some ways, less. I get about 30–60 idiotic questions about the Coronavirus each day and only have time to spend about 1 minute on each one. That really reduces the quality of my answers. And then when people come back with idiotic comments, I have less patience than usual. It doesn’t help that it’s the same questions over and over again. Did God create the coronavirus? Does being black make you more prone to the coronavirus? Was the coronavirus created by 5G? Why is Trump immune to the coronavirus? Can my cat give coronavirus to my dog? Why can’t I get my nails done during a global pandemic? Why did aliens give us the coronavirus? Did NASA bring back the coronavirus from outer space? If a stranger came up and licked your hand, what would you do? Is it safe to turn on my AC? Can I get coronavirus from my camel? I have a boil on my butt. Is that caused by the coronavirus? I don’t believe in the coronavirus. Do you? If I hold my breath outside am I safe from the coronavirus? Can I still go on my around the world cruise during a global pandemic? Can priests cure coronavirus? Why are priests being blamed for the coronavirus?  This is just one fraction of what I get in one day.

I am a very social person and anyone I know can tell you that with one hundred percent confidence. Quarantine has been, no doubt, very difficult for me and it has made me realize my extrovert-ness. I wouldn't say its rubbed me one way or the other as much as the fact that it has made me realize which way I am. There are two sides, introvert and extrovert and I am on the extrovert side. I always saw myself as someone in the middle. I felt as though I could talk to some people and others, I just couldn't. Going into quarantine helped me to realize that I was never afraid to talk to ANYONE. In my head, I felt like I talked to less people than I really did. Like I said, it didn't really rub me one way or the other it just made me realize which side of the spectrum I was on.

I think I am more social this may sound strange but in a way I am more social.. Prior to the lock down I did not have time to call friends and families now I do have time to call them. I spend more time praying with therm. I have more time to email friends etc..yes I more present in the lives of family maybe not in person but in mind.

Thanks Jenine for A2A. I have no idea about that. I am not annoyed by the quarantine; I know that this is a way our religion also suggests. So there is no second opinion about what we are doing. The only problem is that they have closed masjids for ‘jamaat’ prayers. That is not a wise thing to do in a Muslim country. Proper instructions were already being followed but unfortunately a stern decision has been taken. That way I could say that is SOME DROP IN MY BEING SOCIAL, but that is a forced one. However, on phone, WhatsApp, internet and messaging, I am as lively as I should be. I think I am staying ‘at par’. Thanks for reading.

More social, I guess. On a normal basis, I'm always coped up in my room while at home, and never really engage with anyone. I've never really been good at having casual conversations. I view small talk as being time-draining and a waste of time. But since this quarantine, I've gotten to communicating with members of my family. I have small talks with the people I'm living with and surprisingly, I enjoy it. I call my family more often than I normally would. So, I guess it made me social in that way

I’m the same guy as I was before the quarantine. It has not negatively affected me at all because I am active and do various activities around my house and it is really fun and I also spend some time talking with friends online. So yeah, I’ve kept myself busy throughout this time in quarantine and I suggest you should too.

According to me people are more connected now than ever because of the lockdown. Due to this pandemic people are always on the social media interacting with their friends, colleagues, family. Physical contact is reduced drastically but at the other hand people are social connected with the world.

By it’s definition people are less social because they can’t resume their normal life of interaction with others. One way to keep ‘social’ is use the internet either email, Skype, Hangouts, Facebook or other messaging apps.
Neither Jenine, I never have been very sociable. I live off grid in a forest, no one but family to be social with.Keith.
Quarantine has made me less social in-person. However, I have become much more social on Instagram and through text. I have been communicating virtually a lot more now.
Quarantine has made me less social. I am not around society as much until I am. I still remain very psychologically healthy and adaptable.
Obviously, we have become less social. I don’t even talk to much with my friends. I think we have become lazy.

I am the same person, but I think that people may find out more about their attitudes and habits when they are confronted with themselves only. So, nobody really changes, but people get aware of what their preferences are. And, there is nothing that cannot be learned.
